Award.AwardTitle: Transcriptional Regulation of Maize Endosperm Development by IDD9 and IDDveg9 Duplicate Genes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Endosperm is the major storage tissue of cereals and is vastly important for human and livestock nutrition and, increasingly, for industrial purposes. Endosperm comprises several different cell types, each with specific biological functions that influence the biochemical composition and agronomic quality of the grain. Understanding how these cell types are specified and elaborated during development could enable the improvement of grain properties through biotechnology or traditional breeding. This project focuses on an endosperm cell type called aleurone. A maize gene was identified that controls the number of aleurone cells as well as the development of aleurone cell characteristics. This gene, called nkd, is duplicated on two different chromosomes and codes for a transcription factor (a protein that regulates other genes) called IDD9/IDDveg9. As such, the function of this gene is to regulate other genes that are important for endosperm development.

The project will use molecular and genetic approaches to explore the biological function of the nkd gene in endosperm development. The relative position of this gene in the regulatory hierarchy that controls endosperm development will be ascertained by examining the temporal and spatial expression patterns in normal maize grains compared to mutants that are known to affect specific steps in endosperm development. Genome-wide analysis of gene expression will reveal what genes are regulated by IDD9/IDDveg9. Finally, a link will be explored between the nkd gene and the plant hormone auxin. This research is expected to define key steps and molecules in the regulation of endosperm (aleurone) development.

In addition to the biological and potential agronomic implications, important training opportunities will be afforded to young scientists. One postdoctoral fellow, one graduate student, three undergraduate students and three summer interns will contribute to, and benefit from, these research activities. Emphasis will be placed on recruiting from area minority populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The endosperm is the major seed storage tissue in cereal grains from which flour and other important food, feed and industrial feedstock products are derived. The aleurone layer is the outer layer of endosperm cells, which among other things, is important for seed germination, confers many dietary health benefits, and is important for the malting industry. Starchy endosperm cells are the major storage cells, accumulating large quantities of starch and storage proteins. How endosperm formation is regulated during seed development is not well understood. The naked endosperm (nkd) mutant has defects that suggest the normal gene function is required for proper aleurone cell formation.

Intellectual merit:

We molecularly isolated the responsible genes and discovered this function is controlled by duplicated genes on different chromosomes. These genes code for transcription factors, proteins that bind to DNA and regulate the expression of other genes. To discover the genes that the NKD proteins control, aleurone and starchy endosperm cells were isolated from normal and nkd mutant kernels using laser capture microdissection. Messenger RNA from the isolated cells was sequenced to determine all the genes that were expressed in each sample, then the normal versus nkd mutant samples were compared. Genes expressed differently between the samples represent genes that are regulated, either directly or indirectly, by the NKD transcription factor proteins. Both the aleurone and the starchy endosperm samples each contained approximately 2,300 such genes. To determine which of these genes might be directly regulated, DNA binding assays were performed to discover the DNA sequence that is recognized by the NKD proteins. The entire maize genome was searched computationally to occurrences of this recognition sequence and about 30% of the regulated genes contained predicted NKD binding sites in their regulatory regions. Several putative targets of particular interest were confirmed by DNA binding experiments and gene transcription assays.

The NKD-regulated genes were examined for predicted biological, cellular and molecular functions. As anticipated, these included genes involved in cell division and cell growth, regulation of gene expression, genes involved in hormone pathways, and genes associated with aleurone functions. Surprising gene functions included involved in starchy endosperm functions including starch biosynthesis and storage protein accumulation. Genes involved in pathogen defense were also identified. To confirm these results, starch structure was assayed and found to be altered in the nkd mutant, and two storage proteins were found to accumulate to reduced levels.

Several of the genes involved in regulating gene expression are of interest. Particularly noteworthy is the opaque2 (o2) gene which encodes another transcription factor protein. O2 is famous for regulating the expression of several zein storage proteins and the o2 mutant forms the basis for quality protein maize with enhanced levels of essential amino acids including lysine, which is deficient in most cereal grains. Another important gene regulated by NKD is viviparous1 (vp1), which codes for a transcription factor required for aleurone cells to remain viable in dry seeds and to inhibit premature seed germination. NKD also regulates r1, which encodes another well-known transcription factor that regulates anthocyanin pigmentation of aleurone and other plant tissues. In summary, the genes found to be regulated by NKD indicate that the NKD transcription factors are key components of the gene networks that control a wide array of functions important for grain development.
